Context:
Program Name: Food and Nutrition Management
Code: H402
Credential: Ontario College Graduate Certificate
Duration: 1 year (2 semesters)
Starting Months: September
Domestic Tuition: $4,876.00
International Tuition: $18,126.00
Location: St. James Campus
Method of Study: Full-time
Fall 2023 Delivery: Hybrid (Semester 1)
Winter 2024 Delivery: On Campus (Semester 2)
Program Overview: A one-year Food and Nutrition Management graduate certificate program for Hospitality and Culinary Arts graduates with a passion for health care and nutrition. The program focuses on food modification, clinical nutrition, physiology, nutrition analysis, sanitation and safety through classroom instruction and work placements in hospitals, retirement homes, and long-term care facilities.
Related Programs: Culinary Management – Nutrition (H119), Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Culinary Management) (H315), Honours Bachelor of Food Studies (H317)
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Food and Nutrition Management Program (Postgraduate) H402 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The Food and Nutrition Management program at George Brown College is accredited by the Canadian Society of Nutrition Management and is necessary for employment as a Food and Nutrition manager in Ontario. The program schedule is based on a five-day week, Monday to Friday, with classes from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m. Students will complete work-integrated learning opportunities in the student-run café, totaling 35 hours including weekends.

Graduates of this nutrition program will have excellent employment opportunities among growing number of residences and health care facilities serving Canada's increasing population of seniors. As a graduate, you will be eligible to become a member of the Canadian Society of Nutrition Management, allowing you to work as a Food and Nutrition Manager in Ontario's provincially accredited health-care facilities. Your career could lead to positions such as food service supervisor, food manager, nutrition manager, diet technician, or food service director.

Required courses for the program include HOSF 4010: Management Sanitation and Safety, HOST 4003: Menu Analysis, MGMT 4005: Food Service Management, NUTR 4002: Nutrition Analysis, NUTR 4013: Clinical Nutrition I, PHSL 4001: Basic Physiology, COMM 4012: Leadership Communication, HOSF 1146: Emergency First Aid/Heartsaver CPR (weekend course), and HOSF 1287: WHMIS.

Additional fees may apply for becoming a member of the Canadian Society of Nutrition Management.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Food and Nutrition Management Program (Postgraduate) H402 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Program Offered: The college offers a number of courses in various fields including Health Care Standards (HOST 4002), HRM (HRM 4001) - Labour Relations, Clinical Nutrition II (NUTR 4003), Gerontology (PSY 4001), Management Communication (COMM4022), Work-Integrated Learning (HOST4020), Health Care Industry Externship (EXTN4000).

Course Outlines and Program Learning Outcomes: The graduate will be able to plan menus, manage food handling, preparation, and service, manage nutritional needs of diverse clients, support professional work ethics, monitor trends and changes, deliver customer service, manage hiring, coaching, training, scheduling, evaluate staff performance, manage inventory, analyze food and nutrition services, plan and manage budgets, select and use technologies to enhance work performance, and promote food and nutrition services.

Domestic Tuition: $4,876.00
International Tuition: $18,126.00
Additional Costs: The amounts listed are the total of tuition, materials, student service, and ancillary fees for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 20.

No other factual information was extracted from the text.

Context:
Program starting years: Fall 2022, Fall 2023
Estimated total fees for the first two semesters (Fall and Winter): subject to change, see amounts below for estimated values

Amounts:
- Tuition fees: subject to board approval
- Material fees: $400
- Student service and ancillary fees: estimated but not specified

Additional costs:
- Knives and small wares: $500–$700
- Black Safety Shoes: $110–$160
- International Students: refer to the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information

Financial Assistance: OSAP funding is available for applicants who meet eligibility criteria

Admission Requirements:
- Program options: culinary apprenticeship, certificate, diploma, or bachelor’s degree in Culinary or Hospitality Management
- Demonstrated experience (resume required)
- Online interview
- English Language Proficiency: applicants with international transcripts without English proficiency test results must take the college's English assessment
- Course exemptions: college or university credits may qualify for course exemptions, check the Transfer Guide for more information
- Country-specific admission requirements: refer to the International Admissions page
- Pre-placement Health Form: students must meet all mandatory pre-placement health requirements upon acceptance into the program, it may take up to four months to complete all requirements, students are responsible for all costs associated with overall health requirements. For further details and to download the mandatory pre-placement health form, go to the pre-placement page.

Context: Students are required to have a police vulnerable sector check completed for clinical or administrative placement at the college. The process can take between two to three months, but may take up to eight months in some cases. Students are responsible for ensuring that the check covers appropriateness for working with vulnerable persons. The fees for the police record check vary and must be paid by the student. International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. For more information, students can contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions web page for domestic students, and the How to Apply page for international students. Students should note that various allergens are used in practical labs and George Brown College may not meet specific dietary laws related to halal and kosher foods.

George Brown College offers a postgraduate diploma in Food and Nutrition Management, which is accredited by the Canadian Society of Nutrition Managers (CSNM).
Eugene Badal graduated from George Brown College with an Ontario College Graduate Certificate in Food and Nutrition Management. He had interactions with industry professionals who were alumni of the college and expressed admiration for their careers and the values and learning acquired at George Brown. The program was challenging and intensive, but it positioned him to succeed in a management role by providing current and relevant industry insights from practicing industry professionals.
Ways to contact or visit George Brown College include email, phone, virtual meetings, campus tours, info sessions, and signing up to receive tailored resources for application process. Programs offered include Food and Nutrition Management, Culinary Management – Nutrition, Honours Bachelor of Commerce (Culinary Management), and Honours Bachelor of Food Studies.
